Education_2: PhD in Animal Welfare, Honours Degree in Zoology
q1: The fitness, health and productivity of sheep should be protected by adapting their conditions and management to their biology and natural behaviour. They should be given a varied environment with loose material and other enrichments and as much outdoor space as possible, with pasture or browse at least during the growing season.Sheep should be bred and managed for robustness and for ease of birth; this is particularly important where meat production is integrated with dairying. Young should stay with the mothers for several months and then be weaned naturally. Management should be planned to avoid fear and distress from birth to slaughter.
q2: Will orient to the noise, exhibiting the classic startle response. Depending upon the source, the sheep may flee. Over time, if the source does not result in positive or negative consequences, the sheep may habituate and respond less or not at all to the noise. During the initial startle response, the sheep may experience stress.
q3: Will experience significant stress, exhibiting behavioural indicators such as locomotion, vocalisation, attempts to escape the location and head back to the flock, and may tremble. Heart rate and respiration rate may rise, as may plasma and salivary cortisol levels. If prolonged, the rise in cortisol may result in immunosuppression, making the sheep more vulnerable to infectious disease.
q4: May experience less stress than that discussed above regarding isolation, or indeed no stress. However, this will depend upon the behaviour of the animals or people. If they perform behaviour which does engender stress, the habitution responsible for the reduced response may break down.
q5: May experience significant stress, exhibiting behavioural indicators such as locomotion and attempts to escape the location and may tremble. Heart rate and respiration rate may rise, as may plasma and salivary cortisol levels. If prolonged, the rise in cortisol may result in immunosuppression, making the sheep more vulnerable to infectious disease. The behaviour of the unfamiliar animal or person may modify this response over time. If the behaviour towards the sheep is neutral or positive the sheep may habituate to their presence. If it is negative the sheep may not habituate, indeed its behavioural and physiological responses to the stress may intensify.
q6: Will feel fear. If the noise occurs repeatedly the fear felt at each instance may decline over time as the sheep habituates to the noise. If the consequences of the noise are negative (e.g. result in pain, isolation or stress) the fear may intensify.
q7: Will feel fear, lasting for the duration of the isolation.
q8: May experience less fear than that discussed above regarding isolation, or indeed no fear. However, this will depend upon the behaviour of the animals or people. If they perform behaviour which does engender fear, the habitution responsible for the reduced response may break down.
q9: May feel fear. The behaviour of the unfamiliar animal or person may modify this fear over time. If the behaviour towards the sheep is neutral or positive the sheep may habituate to their presence and feel less and eventually no fear. If it is negative the sheep may not habituate, indeed its fear may intensify.
q10: Presence and cleanliness of bedding, repair and maintenance of buildings and equipment.
q11: Cleanliness of feeding and water troughs, quality of feed provided (eg lacking dust and mould). Quantity of feed provided. Animals neither obese nor thin.
q12: Bright eyes, no discharges, no lameness. No lesions or wounds. Normal heart rate, respiration rate and body temprature. No areas of lost, damaged or piloerected coat. Normal faeces and urine colour. Normal interest in surroundings, normal appetite and social behaviour.
q13: Inquisitive and reactive to enviornment, including presence of observer. Not over-reactive to observer- no extreme avoindance responses. Staying with the flock. May approach observer. Normal interest in food.
q14: Extreme avoidance behaviour, extreme reactivity to stimulation. No interest in food or water. Avoiding rest of flock. Stereotypical behaviour. Learned helplessness- ie unresponsive to presence of observer or environmental stimulation.

Education_2: Veterinary Faculty in Bucharest Animal welfare specialization courses in RSPCA-London
q1: 1.the specific and realistic indicators for pain and other disturbative factors for animals have to be established 2.the animal welfare guide to be drawn up based on practical indicators for welfare and auxiliary acts of reglementation to be iisued and applied 3.the animal welfare guide to be in place 4.the welfare guide to be spreaded among farmers and steakholders as well as among backyards owners, 5.a consistent training program with veterinarians in the field(state and private vets)farmers and steakholders as well as among backyards owners,to be performed and applied 6.the farmers and steakholers to be convinced to spend a certain amount of money for fulfiling animal welfare conditions and regulations,being convinced that this expenditure is recovered through health and production of animals,

q4: bu an acceptance approach ,joyness and facies expresion

q10: Sheep are very resistent to bad climatic conditions.So their requirements for housing are not so strict like pigs or veals or horses.But some rules are to be observed: -separate males from females during gestation,farowing and lactation periods -separate pregnant shep from unpregnanat sheep durin gestation,farowing and lactation -ensure enough pasture season at mounteenering area -no special housing conditions but an amount of straw has to be supplied, excepting last stages of gestation ,farowing and one month after, for lambs
q11: -the spring,summera nd autumn pasture is essential -a particular feeding approac during last stage of gestation and the first month after farrowing
q12: -vaccination against antrax -estabilshing specific health surveillance measures have to by drawn up and applied in the framework oh National Strategic Surveillance Programme for Animal Health and Welfare
q13: -a friendly approach in relation with owner or farmers,frequently with other people that is specific for sheep -no scared manifestation -productive and reproductive indicators
q14: -they are scared about every noise -facies is most expresive for abnormal behaviour in sheep -runnind and sometimes hidding

Education_2: Msc Zoology (with interest in Animal behviour)
q1: It needs to have the skills and temperament to survive in the environment it is to live in i.e. fit for purpose. It needs an experienced stockperson able to manage it efficietently within this environment, someone who can provide suitable feed, medicine, housing etc to maintain it's health and enable it to be productive.
q2: Raise it's head, turn to face the direction the noise came from with ears pricked and eyes fixed. If a fear provoking noice it will seek social contact with other sheep, may flock together and head for high ground/corner of pen. If it's a positive noise i.e. quad bike coming with feed, it may vocalise repeatedly and approach the location the noice is coming from.

q5: Is wary, can be fearful and react on insticts alone with little thoughtful response.
q6: may react with fear, feel an adrenaline rush and simple instinctively act. may feel excited, approaching it's lamb, a bag of rustleing feed.

q1: The five freedoms of animal welfare need to be met - its behavioural, physical and health needs should be met.
q2: Depends on the noise. An unfamiliar noise, it will probably startle and retreat away form the noise.   A dam will often move towards offspring if the lamb vocalises. It may be trained to move towards other noises such as food being placed in a pen etc.
q3: Attempts to rejoin the flock, becomes agitated, often vocalises and may show increased activity in attemping to rejoin the mob.
q4: Will show a reduced flight zone / response or may move towards the person depending on the situation / person / relationship / prior experiences
q5: Is likely to retreat away from the person, unless it has had a large amount of positive interaction with people previously.
q6: Is likely to feel stressed at a loud unfamiliar noise. If the noise is her lamb or food, in which case she is likely to feel positive feelings.
q7: Stressed, hypervigilant - in the short term. If isolated for a long time, she may start to show signs of depression, listlesness etc
q8: Sheep are likely to feel more relaxed in the company of familiar animals. They may start to associate a person as a familiar presence in their life and may start to associate the person as a companion. This is more likely to happen if the sheep is housed alone with no other animals for company.
q10: lameness, signs of disease, body condition score, abnormal posture, signs of dehydration, injury
q11: body condition score, emaciation, listlessness, activity, grazing behaviour if on grass,
q12: lameness, signs of disease, injury, alertness, presence of mud / excrement on the fleece,
q13: Alert to noise etc, with the mob, grazing / eating / drinking normally, behaving as the sheep normally would (i.e will move away from people if the sheep usually acts that way)
q14: Listless or hypervigilant, not moving with the mob, not eating / drinking, behaving in any manner different to how the sheep usually would

q1: Companions of its own species. Protection from predators such as dogs, access to suitable nutrition/water.  Protection from inclement weather through wool or shelter such as trees.  Freedom from frequent exposure to invasive and painful husbandry procedures.  Quiet handling.
q2: Depends on the noise.  If novel, sharp or loud sheep may perform startle response, urination, vigilance.  May run away.  If the sound of a conspecific may respond with volcalisation.
q3: Will be vigilant, perform locomotory behviours, vocalise, attempt to return to or find flock mates.
q4: Will follow, perform runimation and resting, affiliative interactions
q5: Flee, be vigilant and orient to the direction of the unfamiliar object/person.  Vocalise, urinate.
q6: Depends on the noise.  If a noise which elicits a fear response the animal is likely to be frightened, anxious.  If the sound of a familiar conspecific the sheep is likely to calm.
q10: Neighbour's sheep are raised extensively in large paddocks.  Lambing paddocks are south west facing with little shelter.  Consequently in cold winters lambing losses are in the vicinity of 30-40%
q11: Amount of pasture in the paddocks being grazed by sheep.  Number of dead sheep in the paddock.  Condition score after shearing.
q12: Dead or flystruck sheep, lambing losses, recumbent sheep at any time. Respiratory rate on hot days when in paddocks with no shade.
q13: Grazing, resting
q14: Flight behaviour of no obvious cause.  Individuals isolated from main flock or groups.

q1: Space in a field (depending on breed) Housing with clean fresh bedding at lambing if weather is bad,  then back out as soon as the lambs are strong and weather better.  Natural feed as much as possible with the right balance of minerals available in a feed block specific to your area. Feet and teeth tended to regularly and a clean backend.
q2: Stop, look then ignore if it's not a threat....depending on the nosie. Most noises they ignore.
q3: ....if it's a Shetland or North Ronaldsay they don't really care, Natural flocking sheep will try to get back to a flock of some kind in a hurry.

q6: depends on the noise, a dog barking viciously will cause distress. A tractor bringing food will have them charging up in anticipation.

q11: Good fleece,  clean backsides, bright eyes and active and looking well.
q12: See above
q13: Quiet grazing,  cudding contentedly, occasional  headbutting between flock members. Occasional gadding about.
q14: Not spending enough time grazing, too much lying about, lying flat out. no gadding about ever. Lying about not cudding. Lethargy. Looking poor.

q1: Yes
q2: What sort of noise? Sheep will come too me if I call, they might be alert at sound of dog, walkers etc They respond to the vocal call of others in the flock. What they do will depend on previous exposure.
q3: depends on the sheep! Depends on the circumstances surrounding the isolation, is the animal lambing, being fed, ill, ??
q4: which?? people or animals - which sheep in relation to which animals or people - what has happened with the "familiar" people do the herd with dogs, do they bring feed, is the sheep hungry, is it tupping or breeding time
q5: See above?
q6: Do you know how a person feels and that is within the same species. This is an impossible question to ask and dangerous to assume that we have any comprehension of how an animal "feels"
q10: What do you mean by this, is this the condition of the building or the condition of the sheep within the building?
q11: Where is this in the housing or on grazing ground?   If I cannot put my hand on the sheep to assess body condition score it is difficult and condition will be related to stage of production.  Or are you asking about the feed "condition" common practice is to have feeds analysed so I would need to talk to him about what he is feeding.
q12: How close can I get? from a distance, mobility, flock behaviour and fleece condition
q13: Normal behaviour? - question is not clear to me
q14: Abnormal behaviour? -question is not clear to me

She usually manifests her displeasure, pain or harmful stress by means of individual behaviors and group or herd behaviors, is separated from the herd "withdrawal", or stampedes occur.
q3: It manifests distress, pain or harmful stress through the grinding of teeth, low head, lip contraction, stare, repetitive motor activity such as kicking the floor, running to one side turn and return several times doing the same route.
q4: It recognizes individuals by the visual cues of the face, can last 2 years. They are very social animals, minimum 5 individuals to facilitate their management. The leakage zone can be used to facilitate movement. Handle them calmly to avoid stamping.
q5: They stampede, they flee from their predators. They increase vocalizations or bleating, gasping, and try to escape as quickly as possible from the place that disturbs them. They memorize negative experiences with humans. They are able to distinguish between known and unknown humans.
q6: Noise is a stressful factor for sheep. Acute sounds affect sheep. They tend to flee, or cause stampedes.
q7: It manifests distress, pain or harmful stress through the grinding of teeth, low head, lip contraction, stare, repetitive motor activity such as kicking the floor, running to one side turn and return several times doing the same route.

q12: It is best to do a detailed analysis of the production or marketing indexes, such as mortality, morbidity. For the individual analysis check for nasal secretions, cough, diarrhea, external parasites. Cachexia, malnutrition, abscesses, injuries, injuries. Observe for wheezing, breathing problems,
q13: the common signs of health are alertness, activity and appetite, in addition to normal growth in young animals and weight maintenance in adult animals. Ruminant movements (normally 3 movements every 2 minutes), belching and rumination should be observed. The sheep is based on the perception of the environment, basically through visual components, social role of visual communication. Social behavior, or flock. The relationship between the individual and the movements is fundamental. The role of smell in the selection of food. Communication in sexual activities and in the mother-offspring effect.
q14: The presence of disease can be indicated by lethargy and inappetence, ocular and nasal discharges, diarrhea and uterine or urinary discharges. Abnormal breathing and cough are signs of tracheal and pulmonary diseases. Behavioral changes include loss of dominance order and, in some circumstances, separation from the herd. The sheep show a very strong gregarious behavior in pens as well as grazing. Isolation of individual sheep brings with it signs of anxiety. The separation of the herd is the main cause of the sheep trying to escape. The lambs tend to follow each other, even in activities such as shepherding, lying, reacting to obstacles and feeding. Displacement; response to low availability of forage. Night grazing vs. diurnal Cohesion of grazing groups. Mutual shading under heat stress. Footprints under barbed wire with low availability. Indian ranks with low availability and in harness. Sleeping rooms. Short sleep periods (40 min). Stereotypes such as eating wool, gnawing poles, walls, excessive licking, among other abnormal behaviors.
